newsitem.title: CANADA: Alliance Pipeline plans nat gas regulatory filings.
newsitem.headline: Alliance Pipeline plans nat gas regulatory filings.

text.p: Alliance Pipeline said on Saturday there was strong industry interest in its plan to build a natural gas pipeline from western Canada to the U.S. Midwest upon completion of a series of consultations on Nov 8, 1996.

"Interest in Alliance's plan to build new, low-cost pipeline capacity from the western Canadian sedimentary basin to the U.S. midwest is very high," Alliance president and chief executive Dennis Cornelson said in a statement.
Allian held eight weeks of consultations with 120 potential shippers. The company's board will meet to approve regulatory filings to the U.S. and Canadian energy regulatory agencies.
"We have taken an important step towards our goal of obtaining firm shipping commitments for gas totaling at least 1.25 billion cubic feet per day," Cornelson said.
The filings before the U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Canadian National Energy Board are scheduled for later this month.
The C$3.6 billion Alliance Pipeline is a 3,000-kilometer (1,900-mile) natural gas transmission system from northeastern British Columbia-northwestern Alberta to the U.S. Midwest.

The pipeline is being developed by limited partnerships comprised of gas producing, marketing and pipeline companies. It is scheduled for start-up at the end of 1999 and will carry 1.25 billion cubic feet of gas per day to Chicago.
The alliance partnership includes Alberta Energy Co Ltd, Gulf Canada Resources Ltd and IPL Energy Inc
